ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained exposure to research being conducted by other students in the department. Gained breadth and depth in techniques and topics in social psychology. Developed presentation skills.
The Intergroup Relations Lab has continued to be a great place to learn from peers and obtain valuable feedback on my research.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One of the major strengths of this lab meeting is how interactive and student-driven it is. The informal nature of the lab meeting creates an environment that encourages the workshopping and brain-storming of ideas and problem-solving as a cohesive group. The lab meeting offers constructive criticism in a very supportive way.

I really love lab. I have a possible controversial suggestion, however: I think it would be great if we could explicitly encourage students to *not* do other work on their computers during lab. I often see people sending emails, working on personal projects, etc. I understand that from time to time people may need to urgently get things done, but some people seem to do this every week, and I think it detracts from an environment of engagement that I otherwise love. If everyone were to work during lab, of course, it would be completely useless.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes; I would encourage other students to attend this lab.
